description: From Latin discriminatus, past participle of discriminare (“to divide, separate, distinguish”), from discrimen (“a space between, division, separation, distinction”), from discerno (“to divide, separate, distinguish, discern”); see discern, discreet, discrete. Compare crime.

adjectives.description: discriminate (comparative more discriminate, superlative most discriminate)

entries.meaning: Having the difference marked; distinguished by certain tokens.

verbs.description: discriminate (third-person singular simple present discriminates, present participle discriminating, simple past and past participle discriminated)

examples: Since he was color blind he was unable to discriminate between the blue and green bottles.

definitionGroups.group: To treat or affect differently, depending on differences in traits.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, construed with against) To make decisions based on prejudice.
examples: The law prohibits discriminating against people based on their skin color.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To set apart as being different; to mark as different; to separate from another by discerning differences; to distinguish.
